questions.question: Patient with longstanding history of intermittent headache. What does the image show?
questions.learning_points: No abnormality is visible. The foci of high density within the lateral ventricles represent calcification of the choroid plexus – a normal finding in adults.

questions.question: History of head injury. Patient unconscious. Which statement is true?
options: The scan is of insufficient quality to make a diagnosis and so should be repeated
There is no evidence of mass effect
Changing window settings would help clarify the diagnosis
A history of anticoagulation is irrelevant in this setting
questions.correct_answer: Changing window settings would help clarify the diagnosis
questions.learning_points:
Image quality is often sub-optimal in acutely unwell patients. An attempt at diagnosis should still be made.
The image demonstrates a subdural collection on the right. In the context of head injury, the crescent-shaped layer of bright material seen over the right cerebral hemisphere represents a recent bleed – a subdural haematoma.
Mass effect is visible. The right lateral ventricle is effaced and there is shift of midline structures to the left.
The roll-over image demonstrates an altered window setting which makes it much easier to see the blood separate from the brain and skull.
Although subdural and subarachnoid bleeding may coexist there is no evidence of subarachnoid blood in this image.
Anticoagulation is a risk factor for intracranial bleeding of all kinds.

questions.question: Patient with a sudden onset of hemianopia. What does this pre-contrast CT brain image demonstrate?
options: Acute haemorrhage in the left basal ganglia
questions.learning_points:
These are the typical appearances of a primary intracerebral haemorrhage. Central high-density acute blood (blue area) is surrounded by low density oedema (red area).
The pineal gland is calcified – a normal finding.
No contrast has been given and so the high density does not represent an enhancing mass
The basal ganglia and internal capsule areas appear normal

questions.question: (Pre and post contrast images): Which description most accurately describes the findings on these two images?
options: Increased density consistent with a subdural collection
Multiple areas of enhancement due to metastases
Areas of abnormally low density with the typical distribution of a territorial infarct
Areas of abnormally low density surrounded by enhancement post IV-contrast
Increased density consistent with an acute primary intracerebral haemorrhage
questions.correct_answer: Areas of abnormally low density surrounded by enhancement post IV-contrast
questions.learning_points:
A very large irregularly-shaped area of abnormally low density is present in the left cerebral hemisphere. This is causing mass effect evidenced by the effacement of the sulci on this side of the brain and shift of midline structures.
The post-contrast image shows enhancement of brain tissue surrounding the low density area.
This mass lesion appears intra-axial (intracerebral) rather than extra-axial (outside the brain).
Although it is possible that a metastasis has this appearance, there is only one lesion and so it is not ‘multiple’.
The appearances are not consistent with an acute primary intracerebral haemorrhage which would be of high density (white) on the pre-contrast image.

questions.question: Patient with history of recent head injury. What does this scan show?
questions.learning_points:
These are the typical appearances of a scalp haematoma.
There is no evidence of intracerebral haemorrhage.
The image is set to ‘brain windows’ so it is not possible to see a skull fracture. To see a skull fracture the window settings should be set to view the bones.

questions.question: (Pre and post contrast CT images of the brain show cerebral metastasis): What else is present?
options: Abnormal low density of white matter representing cerebral oedema
Areas of high density representing recent subarachnoid bleeding
Areas of high density representing recent subdural bleeding
Areas of high density representing recent intracerebral bleeding
questions.correct_answer: Abnormal low density of white matter representing cerebral oedema
questions.learning_points:
A small rounded focus of slightly high density on the pre-contrast image enhances on the post-contrast image. The post-contrast image also shows multiple other foci of enhancement. These are typical appearances of brain metastases.
Both the pre and post-IV contrast images show a large area of abnormally low density within white matter due to cerebral oedema.
Acute bleeding results in areas of high density on the pre-contrast image which would not enhance post contrast.
There is no intracerebral calcification visible on these CT images.

questions.question: Elderly patient with confusion and history of falls. Which abnormality is present?
options: Multiple well-defined foci of low density diagnostic of brain metastases
Low density of cerebral white matter
questions.correct_answer: Low density of cerebral white matter
questions.learning_points:
Patchy low density of cerebral white matter is a sign of chronic small vessel disease.
There are no well-defined foci of low density.
There is no well-defined area of low density of grey and white matter in a territorial distribution to indicate the presence of an old territorial infarct.
No subdural collection is present.

questions.question: CT brain on bone window settings - 2 images: Which anatomical structure is highlighted in orange on image 2?
questions.learning_points:
The sinuses of the skull contain air and so are completely black on CT; they have the same density as the air surrounding the head.
The sphenoid sinus is highlighted in orange (roll-over image). It has very variable appearance and can be split into two or more compartments.
The pituitary fossa (not visible) contains the pituitary gland which is of similar density to the brain.
Some of the other sinuses and air cells of the skull are highlighted.

questions.question: Which clinical feature(s) would you expect to be present in this patient?
options: Asymptomatic with no focal neurological deficit
Recent onset of isolated left cerebellar signs
Normal power in both arms and reduced power in both legs
questions.learning_points:
A large area of low density is seen in the grey and white matter of the left cerebral hemisphere indicating a large middle cerebral artery territory infarct. It is possible to determine that the infarct is recent; in the case of old infarcts the low density would be similar to that of the CSF in the ventricles.
Clinically the patient would have a significant neurological deficit in accordance to the anatomical area affected. In this case the patient would have a right hemiparesis.
The patient could also have cerebellar signs, if the posterior circulation was also affected, but this would not be an isolated clinical feature in this case.

questions.question: Non-contrast CT brain: Patient found unconscious. Which finding is visible?
options: Normal calcification of the choroid plexus
Abnormal high-density material in the subarachnoid space
questions.correct_answer: Abnormal high-density material in the subarachnoid space
questions.learning_points:
High density material in the subarachnoid spaces (the sulci, fissures and ventricular system) indicates acute subarachnoid haemorrhage.
There is no evidence of acute intracerebral haemorrhage, subdural collections, or reduced brain volume. There is no intracerebral calcification visible.
